metadata.title: Two-site silica supported Fe/Cr catalysts for tailoring bimodal polyethylenes with variable content of UHMWPE

Two-site silica supported Fe/Cr catalysts for tailoring bimodal polyethylenes with variable content of UHMWPE Alexander Kurek a Stefan Mark b Markus Enders b Markus Stürzel a Rolf Mülhaupt a ⁎ a Freiburg Materials Research Center, FMF and Institute for Macromolecular Chemistry, Albert-Ludwigs-Universität Freiburg, Stefan-Meier-Strasse 21, D-79104 Freiburg, Germany Freiburg Materials Research Center, FMF and Institute for Macromolecular Chemistry, Albert-Ludwigs-Universität Freiburg Stefan-Meier-Strasse 21 Freiburg D-79104 Germany b Anorganisch Chemisches Institut, Ruprecht-Karls-Universität Heidelberg, Im Neuenheimer Feld 270, D-69120 Heidelberg, Germany Anorganisch Chemisches Institut, Ruprecht-Karls-Universität Heidelberg Im Neuenheimer Feld 270 Heidelberg D-69120 Germany ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +49 7612036270. Graphical abstract A new family of Fe/Cr-based supported dual-site catalysts were prepared by means of sequential and simultaneous immobilization (“cosupporting”) of two single-site catalysts on MAO pretreated silica. The influence of catalyst preparation, catalyst composition, and of Fe/Cr molar ratio on catalyst activity, polyethylene (PE) molecular weight (MW), and PE molecular weight distribution (MWD), as determined by high temperature size exclusion chromatography, was examined. A new family of silica supported two-site Fe/Cr catalysts were prepared by means of sequential and simultaneous immobilization (“cosupporting”) of both 2,6-bis-[1-(2,6-dimethylphenyliminio)ethyl]pyridine iron(II) chloride (Fe) and η5-[3,4,5-trimethyl-1-(8-quinolyl)-2-trimethyl-silylcyclopentadienyl]chromium(III) chloride (Cr) on MAO-pretreated silica. The influence of catalyst preparation, catalyst composition, and of Fe/Cr molar ratio on catalyst activity, polyethylene (PE) molecular weight (MW), and PE molecular weight distribution (MWD), as determined by high temperature size exclusion chromatography, was examined. Catalyst activity increased with decreasing transition metal content. The average molar masses of the two PE fractions, UHMWPE (3×106 g/mol), produced on Cr sites, and PE (3×105 g/mol), produced on Fe sites, are independent of the Fe/Cr molar ratio. The sequential immobilization of the Fe complex prior to the Cr complex affords the highest catalyst activities and highest UHMWPE contents. Here, the UHMWPE content consequently increases from 0 to 32wt% with increasing Cr content at constant Fe concentration. Keywords Supported catalyst Post-metallocene Ethylene polymerization Ultrahigh molecular weight polyethylene Single-site catalyst Bimodal molar mass distribution 1 Introduction Single-site catalysts have received considerable attention because they enable tailoring of polyolefins with excellent control of molar mass (MW) and comonomer incorporation [1–3]. Polymer melt processing strongly depends upon both the average MW and the molar mass distribution (MWD). In fact, polyolefins with narrow MWD, produced by single site catalysts, are rather difficult to process. For enabling shear thinning in melt processing, it is an important objective in polyolefin development to control the MWD by incorporating UHMWPE. Moreover, small amounts of UHMWPE in PE with bimodal molar mass distributions account for melt strengthening, which is attractive in melt extrusion and blow molding processes [4–6]. Small amounts of UHMWPE also function as “tie molecules“, linking together PE crystallites, thus improving mechanical properties and fatigue life of HDPE pipes [4]. Today, melt compounding as well as reactor blend technologies are employed to control both MW and MWD of polyolefins [7]. Owing to their very high melt viscosities and mixing problems, melt blending of UHMWPE with PE is rather difficult [8]. As a consequence, PE with bimodal molar mass distributions is obtained by means of multi-reactor technology. Typically, cascades of reactors operate at different polymerization conditions with variations of temperature, pressure, and hydrogen partial pressure [5,9,10]. Although cascade reactor technology is widely used in polyolefin industry, an alternative strategy exploits catalytic olefin polymerization on multi-site catalysts, simultaneously producing low and ultrahigh molecular weight polymers in a single reactor [11,12]. In spite of obvious benefits of such mixed catalysts in olefin polymerization, it is rather difficult to control MWD over a wide range because different sites interact with each other or with activator alkyls, respectively. Frequently, complex mixtures are formed by multi-site catalysts, because polymer MW varies as a function of catalyst composition and polymerization process parameters. Hence, it is an important objective in polyolefin research to explore blends of single site catalysts, which do not interact and form robust two-site catalyst systems, especially with respect to the influence of polymerization and catalyst preparation procedures. The ideal multi-site catalyst should enable MWD control by varying the blend ratio of low and UHMWPE as a function of the molar ratio of the different catalytic sites without affecting the MW of these PE fractions, produced on different contiguous sites [11,12]. Most studies on multi-site catalysts and PE reactor blend formation employ blends of homogeneous single-site catalysts [13–20]. However, for the industrial gas phase and slurry polymerization processes, the heterogenization of homogeneous catalysts on a solid support represents a prime requirement for preventing reactor fouling [21]. Therefore, two or more single-site catalysts are immobilized on the same support [22–27]. For example, polyethylene with mono- and bimodal MWD was obtained by cosupporting of Et(Ind)2ZrCl2 with Cp2HfCl2 [28]. While several supported two-site and also multiple-single site metallocene catalysts have been reported, much less is known with respect to cosupporting of post-metallocene catalysts. Supported post-metallocene multi-site catalysts were obtained by cosupporting of IndZr(O2C t Bu)3 with various zirconium-based post-metallocenes [12]. Besides the use of two single-site catalysts, also the combination of Ziegler catalysts with metallocene catalysts has been examined with respect to reactor blend formation and MWD control [7,29–36]. Herein we report on silica-supported two-site post-metallocene catalysts by means of sequential and simultaneous immobilization of 2,6-bis-[1-(2,6-dimethylpenyliminio)ethyl]pyridine iron(II) chloride (Fe), producing HDPE with low MW of about 3×105 g/mol, together with η5-[3,4,5-trimethyl-1-(8-quinolyl)-2-trimethyl-silylcyclopentadienyl]chromium(III) chloride (Cr), producing UHMWPE with MW exceeding 3×106 g/mol. The architectures of both complexes are displayed in Fig. 1 . The MWD of the supported single-site Fe and Cr catalysts is shown in Fig. 2 . The influence of two-site catalyst preparation, transition metal content, and Fe/Cr molar ratio on catalysts activity in ethylene polymerization, PE molecular weight and PE MWD is investigated. MW and MWD are analyzed by means of high temperature size exclusion chromatography (HT-SEC) in order to examine the composition of reactor blends containing low and UHMWPE. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials (chemicals) The silica support (1220m2/g) was prepared according to literature [37]. Typically, it was dried under vacuum (P <10−4 mbar) for 3h at 423K and after cooling to room temperature stored under argon. MAO was supplied by Crompton (10wt% toluene solution). The catalysts 2,6-bis-[1-(2,6-dimethylphenyliminio)ethyl]pyridine iron(II) chloride [38,39] (Fe) and [η5-3,4,5-trimethyl-1-(8-chinolyl)-2-trimethylsilylcyclopentadienyl]chromium(III)-dichloride [40] (Cr) were prepared according to literature. Ethylene (2.8) and argon (5.0), both provided by Air Liquide, were used without further purification. Pure toluene and n-heptane, purchased from Merck were deoxygenated and dried by standard techniques before use. Triisobutylaluminum (1M solution in hexane, TiBAl) was purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of supported catalysts All described experiments were performed under inert atmosphere using standard Schlenk technique. Typically, 1.5g of dried silica was stirred in 15mL of toluene and 7.5mL of MAO solution at room temperature for 45min. After sedimentation, the supernatant liquid was removed with a pipette. After washing the solid twice with 10mL of toluene, the solvent was reduced with vacuum (p <10−4 mbar), and the so-called activated (MAO-modified) silica stored under argon. The activation procedure was carried out in a way that the cocatalysts solution was completely immobilized on the silica. For the preparation of the cosupported catalysts a solution of Fe and/or Cr in toluene (0.1mg/mL) were added to 50mg of activated silica and stirred for 5min. After sedimentation, the supernatant liquid, which showed no coloring and no indication for the presence of transition metal complexes, was removed with a pipette and the procedure repeated with the other catalyst. The procedure was carried out until the complete amount of catalyst was immobilized. After completing the immobilization process 10mL of n-heptane were added to the catalyst particles. 2.3 Polymerization procedure Polymerizations were carried out in a 200mL double jacket steel reactor connected to a thermostat and equipped with mechanical stirring. The reactor was filled with 80mL of n-heptane, and 0.5mmol of TiBAl was added as scavenger. For each experiment the catalyst particles were suspended in 10mL of n-heptane and then injected in the reactor. In order to assure the transfer of the entire particles this procedure was repeated once. After the addition of the catalyst the polymerization was started. During the polymerization period of 60min the ethylene pressure was kept constant at 3bar, the temperature at 40°C, and the stirring speed at 1000rpm. Afterwards the polymer was filtered off and dried for 12h at 60°C under reduced pressure. 2.4 Polyethylene characterization The MW, MWD, and UHMWPE content of the polymers were determined using a PL-220 size exclusion chromatograph (Polymer Laboratories) equipped with a differential refractive index (DRI) detector, the differential viscometer 210 R (Viscotek), and a low-angle light scattering (LASS) detector. The measurements were performed at 150°C with 3 PLGel Olexis columns and 1,2,4-Trichlorobenzene (Merck) stabilized with 0.2wt% of 2,6-di-tert-butyl-(4-methylphenol) (Aldrich) was used as solvent at a flow rate of 1.0mL/min. Columns were calibrated using 12 polystyrene samples with narrow MWD. Molecular weight (Mn, Mw, Mz) was calculated using universal calibration. For the measurement of the polyethylene samples triple detection was applied. UHMWPE was defined having a molar mass higher than 106 g/mol and was calculated by integration of the measured SEC data. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The influence of sequential and simultaneous immobilization The Fe and Cr complexes were supported on MAO-treated silica using a process reported by Soares and coworkers for the immobilization of metallocene catalysts [25]. Three different procedures for Fe and Cr addition were employed. In the sequential catalyst immobilization (“cosupporting”), either the Fe or the Cr complex was added prior to the addition of the other complex. This addition mode is indicated by the sample code Cr/Fe, denoting that Cr was immobilized on silica prior to Fe addition. The simultaneous addition of Fe together with Cr is indicated by the sample code Fe+Cr. The Fe/Cr molar ratio and the amount of the silica support were constant, using 50mg silica and Fe/Cr molar ratio of 10:7. Since no leaching was detected during washing cycles, all Fe and Cr complexes were immobilized on the support. Furthermore, the liquid phase recovered by washing showed no catalytic activity in ethylene polymerization when MAO was added. Catalyst activities together with the MWD and the content of UHMWPE are listed in Table 1 as a function of the procedures employed for the single site catalyst formation. The corresponding MWD is displayed in Fig. 3 . As is apparent from Table 1 and Fig. 3, when Cr was cosupported with Fe on silica, the MWD was much broader with respect to that of PE produced on the corresponding single-site Fe catalyst. The obtained PE reactor blend exhibited bimodal MWD and contained UHMWPE with MW of 3×106 g/mol together with lower MW PE of 3×105 g/mol. The average MW of the two PE fractions did not depend upon the cosupporting procedures. In fact, the average MW of both PE fractions was very similar to those obtained with the corresponding supported single-site Cr and Fe catalysts. The highest MW and the highest content of UHMWPE (31.8wt%) was achieved by the sequential supporting of Fe/Cr, whereas the lowest MW, and lowest UHMWPE content (10.8wt%) was produced by the simultaneous cosupporting of both catalysts (Fe+Cr). Hence, the activity of both catalysts and the ratio of the two MW fractions of the reactor blend were influenced by the cosupporting process, especially the sequence of the post-metallocene addition. The content of active chromium sites and their influence on molar mass was calculated using Eqs. (1) and (2), in order to examine the influence of the Cr, Fe supporting sequence on the reactor blend composition. (1) Mw = w ( Cr ) ⋅ Mw ( Cr ) + ( 1 − w ( Cr ) ) ⋅ Mw ( Fe ) (2) mol % ( Cr ) theo = Mw exp − Mw ( Fe ) Mw ( Cr ) − Mw ( Fe ) × 100 % According to Eq. (1), the weight average molecular weight of the Fe/Cr binary blend, supported independently on silica, is calculated as Mw=1550kgmol−1. The deviance of the calculated values range from 37% to 334% (cf. entry 3–5 in Table 1). On comparing the calculated values (Eq. (2)) with the experimental results, the content of chromium sites are strongly decreased from 27.2% to 5.5%. The overall activities of the two-site catalysts were lower than that of the corresponding single-site Fe catalyst. Most likely, UHMWPE formation impaired catalyst activity due to diffusion limitation [41]. This is consistent with the observation that the catalyst system (sample 3, Table 1), producing the reactor blend with the lowest UHMWPE content, gave the highest catalytic activity. 3.2 The influence of the transition metal content In order to investigate the influence of total transition metal content on ethylene polymerization, the amount of silica was increased from 50mg to 150mg using the same total amount of immobilized transition metal at constant Fe/Cr molar ratio of 10:7. As is apparent from Table 2 and the MWD displayed in Fig. 4 , MW and MWD were almost unaffected by the transition metal content of the supported catalysts. Calculating the Cr content according to Eq. (2) indicates that with increasing silica content from 50 to 150mg the activity is lowered by 10%. The average Mw decreased from 3.35×106 g/mol to 3.09×106 g/mol (cf. entry 9–11, Table 2. Yet, the catalyst activities increased significantly with decreasing transition metal content. This is represents another experimental evidence that there exist no detrimental interactions between the two single Fe and Cr containing catalytic sites, independent of the distances between individual sites on the support. As reported above, the losses of catalyst activities encountered at high transition metal content, is likely to be associated with diffusion limitations and probably also hot spot formation known for many other supported catalyst systems. 3.3 The influence of the Fe/Cr molar ration ethylene polymerization Since cosupporting did not affect the MW of the PE fractions produced on Fe and Cr sites, it should be possible to control MWD by varying the UHMWPE content via the Fe/Cr molar ratio. As cosupported Fe/Cr catalysts produced reactor blends with the highest MW and highest UHMWPE content, they were employed to examine this concept of MWD control via Fe/Cr molar ratio variation. While the total amount of Fe supported on silica was maintained constant, the Cr content was lowered with respect to Fe. The results of these polymerizations are listed in Table 3 . It is obvious that the Fe/Cr molar ratio afforded very effective control of the MWD. While the Fe/Cr catalyst containing 41.0mol% Cr (21, Table 3) produced PE with a average MW exceeding 0.9×106 g/mol, lowering the Cr content to 18.8mol% (24) gave much lower average MW of about 0.4×106 g/mol. As is apparent from Fig. 5 , there exists a linear correlation between UHMWPE content and the amount of Cr in the Fe/Cr two-site catalyst. Most likely, as a result of diffusion limitations and differences in polymerization rate/time functions of the two sites, such a linear correlation did not exist between Cr content and catalyst activity. According to the examination of PE MWD, displayed in Fig. 6 , the variation of the Fe/Cr ratio affected exclusively the weight ratio of UHMWPE und low MW PE but did not affect the average MW of the individual PE fractions. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, simultaneous and sequential immobilization (“cosupporting”) of Fe and Cr based post metallocenes on the MAO-tethered silica support afford a versatile two-site catalyst family. They contain catalytically active Cr single-sites, producing UHMWPE, and Fe single-sites, producing lower MW PE. Hence, such cosupported two-site catalysts produce PE reactor blends with bimodal MWD containing variable amounts of UHMWPE. The Fe/Cr molar ratio controls the weight ratio of both PE fractions but does not affect their average MW. The sequential cosupporting of Fe/Cr is preferred with respect to simultaneous cosupporting Fe+Cr with respect to achieving high content of UHMW. While UHMWPE formation impairs catalyst activities, most likely due to diffusion limitations, the MWD control with Fe/Cr two-site catalysts is remarkably robust, enabling stable operation and facile MWD control. The linear correlation between Cr content of Fe/Cr catalyst permits easy selection of MWD ranges. Moreover, cosupporting can be expanded from two-site catalysts to a great variety of multiple-single-site catalysts producing bi-, tri- and multimodal polyethylene MWDs, which are readily tailored to match the demands of individual applications. The manufacturing of tailor-made polyolefins via cosupported multiple single-site catalysts represents a very versatile tool for polyolefin synthesis, which can be employed to achieve improved control of mechanical and rheological properties. As will be reported elsewhere in more detail, the proximity of sites producing UHMWPE and low molecular weight PE enables the production of PE reactor blends containing high UHMWPE content without sacrificing melt processability. coredata.dc:description: A new family of silica supported two-site Fe/Cr catalysts were prepared by means of sequential and simultaneous immobilization (“cosupporting”) of both 2,6-bis-[1-(2,6-dimethylphenyliminio)ethyl]pyridine iron(II) chloride (Fe) and η5-[3,4,5-trimethyl-1-(8-quinolyl)-2-trimethyl-silylcyclopentadienyl]chromium(III) chloride (Cr) on MAO-pretreated silica. The influence of catalyst preparation, catalyst composition, and of Fe/Cr molar ratio on catalyst activity, polyethylene (PE) molecular weight (MW), and PE molecular weight distribution (MWD), as determined by high temperature size exclusion chromatography, was examined. Catalyst activity increased with decreasing transition metal content. The average molar masses of the two PE fractions, UHMWPE (3×106 g/mol), produced on Cr sites, and PE (3×105 g/mol), produced on Fe sites, are independent of the Fe/Cr molar ratio. The sequential immobilization of the Fe complex prior to the Cr complex affords the highest catalyst activities and highest UHMWPE contents. Here, the UHMWPE content consequently increases from 0 to 32wt% with increasing Cr content at constant Fe concentration.
coredata.dc:title: Two-site silica supported Fe/Cr catalysts for tailoring bimodal polyethylenes with variable content of UHMWPE
